facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 22 of 1961 by special leave against award of Industrial Tribunal, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION. Civil Appeal No. 22 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the award dated October 3, 1959, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference T.  No. 33 of 1959. Ramaswamy, E. Udavarathnam and S. S. Shukla, for the appellants. Ramamurthy Iyer and R. Gopalkrishnan, for the respondent No. 1. 1961. September 27.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal, Bombay awarded on October 3, 1959, rejecting reference for lack of jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH. J.-This is an appeal with special leave against an award of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay. By its award the Tribunal rejected the reference holding that it had numberjurisdiction to adjudicate upon the dispute submitted to it by the Government of Bombay.

facts.text: Salivateeswaran claimed to be a full time employee of the first respondent The Hindu, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Salivateeswaran  the third appellant  who claimed to be a full time employee of the first respondent. The Hindu, Bombay-addressed a letter on February 15, 1956, to the Managing Editor of The Hindu-a daily newspaper published at Madras intimating that he was proceeding to Europe on March 1, 1956.

facts.text: Salivateeswaran addressed letter on February 15, 1956 to Managing Editor of The Hindu intimating proceeding to Europe on March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On February 16, 1956, the Assistant Editor of The Hindu informed Salivateeswaran that even though the latter was number a full time employee of -The Hindu, they companyld number allow frequent breaks in the performance of of his duties and that they would have to relieve him of his duties as companyrespondent from March 1, 1956, if he proceeded to Europe as arranged by him.

facts.text: On February 16, 1956, Assistant Editor of The Hindu informed Salivateeswaran that he was not a full time employee and would be relieved from March 1, 1956 if he proceeds to Europe.

anchor.surface_text: Salivateeswaran having persisted in carrying out his project by letter dated February 29, 1956, he was informed by the Management that lie ceased to be a companyrespondent of The Hindu from March 1, 1956. After returning from his tour of Europe, Salivateeswaran, on July 5, 1956, demanded reinstatement and called upon the management of The Hindu to treat the period of his absence out of India as leave.

facts.text: Management informed Salivateeswaran by letter dated February 29, 1956 that he ceased to be correspondent from March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The management of The Hindu having declined to accede to that demand, Salivateeswaran filed an application under s. 17 of the Bombay Working Journalist  Conditions of Service  and Miscellaneous Provisions Act 45 of 1955, claiming Rs. 1,57,172-8-0 under diverse heads alleging that termination of his employment was wrongful and that it amounted to retrenchment.

facts.text: On July 5, 1956, Salivateeswaran demanded reinstatement and treatment of absence as leave.

anchor.surface_text: The manage, meat of The Hindu denied that Salivateeswarn was their employee and submitted that the Authority under Act 45 of 1955 had numberjurisdiction to decide disputed questions of fact. The Authority rejected this companytention holding that he was companypetent to decide disputed questions arising in the case before him.

facts.text: Salivateeswaran filed application under s.17 of Bombay Working Journalists Act 45/1955 claiming Rs.1,57,172-8-0 for wrongful termination.

anchor.surface_text: The management of The Hindu presented a petition under Act. 32 of the Constitu- tion for a direction quashing the order of the Authority., companytending that s. 17 of the Act did number empower the Authority to act as a forum for adjudicating disputed claims. This Court upheld  see Kasturi and Sons  Private  Ltd. v. Salivateeswaran 1  the plea of the Management of The Hindu, but dismissed the petition holding that numberfundamental right of the Management was infringed by the order passed by the Authority.

facts.text: The Hindu denied Salivateeswaran was employee and challenged jurisdiction under Act 45/1955.

anchor.surface_text: Acting on the view expressed by this Court the Authority declined to proceed with the application, because disputed questions of fact fell to be determined in the petition before him. The Hindu had an office in Bombay since 1937. At the material time., The Hindu had besides Salivateeswaran only -nine employees-seven serving on the administrative side and two journalists-Venkateawaran and Tiwari.

facts.text: The Hindu had office in Bombay since 1937 with nine employees including Salivateeswaran, Venkateswaran and Tiwari as journalists.

anchor.surface_text: Salivateeswaran and Venkateswaran were members of the Bombay Union of Journalists Tiwari, the other journalist employee,, was number a member of the Union. The Bombay Union of Journalists is a Trade Union, the membership of which is open to all persons who depend for their livelihood upon the practice of the profession of journalism, including press photographers, artists, cartoonist and free-lance writers.

facts.text: Bombay Union of Journalists supported Salivateeswaran's claim by resolution dated August 16, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This Union is admittedly number a Union of employees of The Hindu, Bombay, but it is a Union of all persons who depend for their livelihood upon journalism in Bombay. By its resolution dated August 16, 1956, the Bombay Union of Journalists supported the claim of Salivateeswaran in the application filed by him under s. 17 of Act 45 of 1955.

facts.text: Between April 9, 1958 and April 15, 1958, 225 members of Union wrote letters supporting Salivateeswaran's cause.

anchor.surface_text: 1  1959 S. C. R 1. Between April 9, 1958, and April 15 1958, four letters were addressed by 225, members of the Union  amongst whom Venkateswaran was number included  informing the Union that the termination of employment of Salivateeswaran. raised questions of principle and it was necessary that there should be a proper adjudication in which the principles may be settled and therefore they supported the cause of Salivateeswaran

facts.text: Union meeting on April 17, 1958 resolved to support Salivateeswaran's dispute with The Hindu Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: and requested the Union to take all appropriate steps to approach the state of Bombay for referring the dispute to an appropriate tribunal for adjudication unders. 10  1  c  of the Industrial Disputes Act. The Union claims that these letters amounted to a requisition for calling a meeting and that they were placed before an adjourned meeting of the General Body on April 17, 1958, held under the chairmanship of one D. V. Nathan, and in that meeting it was resolved to support the cause of Salivateeswaran in the dispute with The HinduBombay.

facts.text: On April 25, 1958, Union wrote to Proprietor of The Hindu Bombay to settle dispute.

anchor.surface_text: On April 25, 1958, the Union wrote to the Proprietor of The Hindu Bombay to settle the dispute raised by Salivateeswaran. The Hindu Bombay having declined to accede to the request, the Union moved the Conciliation Officer appointed under the Industrial Disputes Act to intervene.

facts.text: Conciliation Officer reported failure on December 5, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute was taken up for Conciliation by the Conciliation Officer, Bombay, but after holding several meetings with the parties, the Conciliation Officer by his report dated December 5, 1958, reported failure in his efforts to bring about companyciliation Thereafter, on February 9, 1959, the State of Bombay referred the dispute between The Hindu, Bombay, and Salivateeswaran for adjudication under s. 12 5  of the Industrial Disputes Act,1947.

facts.text: State of Bombay referred dispute on February 9, 1959 under s.12(5) Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: No. AJN. 7458-H-Whereas the Government of Bombay has companysidered the report submitted by the Conciliation Officer under sub-section  4  of section 12 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  XIV of 1947 , in respect of the dispute between the Hindu, Bombay and the workman  Working Journalists  employed under it over the demands mentioned in the Schedule appended hereto And whereas the Government of Bombay are companysidering the aforesaid report is satisfied that there is a case for reference of the dispute to a Tribunal

facts.text: Reference claimed Rs.1,52,172-8-0 under diverse heads for Salivateeswaran.

anchor.surface_text: Now, therefore, in exercise of the powers companyferred by sub- section  5  of the Section 12 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  XIV of 1947 , read with Section 3 of the Working Journalists  Conditions of Service  and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955  XIV of 1955 , the Government of Bombay hereby refers the said dispute for adjudication to the Tribunal companysisting of Shri M. H. Meher companystituted-under Government Notification, Labour and, Social Welfare Department, No. IDA. 1157 b  dated the 12th March, 1957.

facts.text: The Hindu challenged Tribunal's jurisdiction on three grounds including no industrial establishment, no employee relation, individual dispute.

anchor.surface_text: By the Schedule, the claim of Salivateeswaran to receive in the aggregate Rs. 1,52,172-8-0 under, diverse heads was set out. The Hindu, Bombay, challenged the companypetence of the State Government to refer this dispute on three grounds  1  that there was numberindustrials establishment, of The Hindu in Bombay and, therefore, the Industrial Tribunal had numberjurisdiction in. the matter  2  that Salivateeswaran was number a working journalist within the meaning of the Act and was number employed as such by The.Hindu , and there being numberrelationship of employer and employee between The Hindu, and Salivateeswaran, the Industrial Tribunal had numberjurisdiction.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected first two grounds but upheld third: individual dispute not supported by appreciable number of employees.

anchor.surface_text: to adjudicate upon the dispute and 3  that there was numberdispute between the Working Journalists of The Hindu, Bombay , on the one hand and the Management on the other and the dispute raised by Salivateeswaran was merely an individual dispute which was number supported by an appreciable number of employees of The Hindu Bombay. The Tribunal rejected the first and the second grounds but upheld the third, and holding that the dispute was merely an individual dispute between Salivateeswaran and The Hindu, Bombay, which had number been supported by an appreciable number of employees of The Hindu, Bombay, the Government of Bombay had numberjurisdiction to refer the dispute to the Tribunal

facts.text: Venkateswaran and Tiwari filed affidavits stating they did not support Salivateeswaran's dispute.

anchor.surface_text: Venkateswaran and Tiwari filed affidavits before the Tribunal stating that the dispute between Salivateeswaran and the management of The Hindu was purely a personal affair of the former and that they had number made companymon cause with him in regard to the dispute or adopted his dispute as their own. Venkateswaran and Tiwari stated in their affidavits that they had number at any time, number did they support Salivateeswarans claim in any manner.

facts.text: Court finds evidence of April 17, 1958 resolution unsatisfactory and fabricated.

anchor.surface_text: For reasons to be presently set out, we are of the view that the evidence tends to establish the plea raised by the first respondent that the record of the alleged resolution was fabricated with a view to support the case of Salivateeswaran. The alleged meeting of April 17, 1958, was number companyvened as an Extraordinary General meeting of the Union.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds dispute is individual, not industrial, as not supported by Union of The Hindu employees or appreciable number.

arguments.claim: A dispute between employer and single employee cannot per se be industrial dispute but becomes one if taken up by union or number of workmen with considerable reason.

anchor.surface_text: In Central Provinces Transport Services Ltd. v. Raghunath Gopal Patwardhan  1 , this Court after setting out the three possible views on the question whether a dispute by an individual workman may be regarded as an industrial dispute within the meaning of s. 2 k  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 observed The preponderance of judicial opinion is clearly in favour

arguments.claim: Scheme of Industrial Disputes Act contemplates settling disputes involving class rights of workmen, not individual unless taken up by union or number of workmen.

anchor.surface_text: of the last of the three views ,stated above  i. e. a dispute between an employer and a single employee cannot per se be an industrial dispute, but it may become one if it is taken up by the Union or a number of workmen and there is companysiderable reason behind it. Notwithstanding that the language of s. 2 k  is wide enough

arguments.claim: Applicability of Industrial Disputes Act to individual dispute excluded unless workmen as body or considerable section make common cause.

anchor.surface_text: This view was reiterated in The Newspapers Ltd. v.The State industrial Tribunal. U. P.,  i  Therefore, the applicability of the industrial Disputes Act to an individual dispute as distingushed from a dispute involving a group of workmen a excluded, unless the workmen as a body or a companysiderable section of them make companymon cause with individual workman.

arguments.claim: Two tests for industrial dispute: real dispute capable of settlement; parties have direct or substantial interest in employment of person concerned.

anchor.surface_text: For reasons to be presently set out, we are of the view that the evidence tends to establish the plea raised by the first respondent that the record of the alleged resolution was fabricated with a view to support the case of Salivateeswaran.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: reasonably be inferred that these employees had acted in companycert, but there is numberreason to suppose that they were, as companytended by Salivat

arguments.court_reasoning: Detailed analysis of testimony, documents, lack of notice/minutes, discrepancies confirm fabrication

holdings.text: a dispute between an employer and a single employee cannot per se be an industrial dispute, but it may become one if it is taken up by the Union or a number of workmen and there is considerable reason behind it. Notwithstanding that the language of s. 2(k) is wide enough to cover a dispute between an employer and a single employee, the scheme of the Industrial Disputes Act does appear to contemplate that the machinery provided therein should be set in motion, to settle only disputes which involve the rights of workmen as a class and that a dispute touching the individual rights of a workman was not intended to be the subject of an adjudication under the Act, when the same had not been taken up by the Union or a number of workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute, in the present case, being prima facie, an individual dispute, in order that it may become an industrial dispute it had to be established that it had been taken up by the Union of employees of The, Hindu, Bombay, or by an appreciable number of employees of The Hindu, Bombay. Counsel for the appellant contended that the dispute was supported by the Bombay Union of Journalists of which Salivateeswaran was a member and that, in any event, it was supported by Venkateswaran and Tiwari, who were the only other employees

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses preponderance of judicial opinion from precedents like Central Provinces Transport Services Ltd. and interprets scheme of Industrial Disputes Act as contemplating class rights over individual disputes unless supported by union or number of workmen.

holdings.text: Support of the cause, by the Union, will not in our judgment convert the individual dispute of one of its members into an industrial dispute.

anchor.surface_text: By its constitution the Bombay Union of Journalists is a Union not of employees of one employer, but of all employees in the industry of journalism in Bombay. Support of the cause, by the Union, will not in our judgment convert the individual dispute

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bombay Union of Journalists is a general trade union for all journalists in Bombay, not specific union of The Hindu employees; applies substantial interest requirement from Dimakuchi.

holdings.text: the principle that the persons who seek to support the cause of a workman must themselves be directly and substantially interested in the dispute in our view applies to this class of cases also persons who are not employees of the same employer cannot be regarded as so interested, that by their support they may convert an individual dispute into an industrial dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The principle that the persons who seek to support the cause of a workman must themselves be directly and substantially interested in the dispute in our, view applies to this class of cases also persons who are not employees of the the, same employer cannot be regarded as so interested, that by their support they may convert an individual dispute into an industrial dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extends Dimakuchi Tea Estate's two tests (real dispute and direct/substantial interest) to require supporters to be employees of the same employer for conversion to industrial dispute.

holdings.text: there was, in fact, no support to the cause of Salivateeswaran by Venkateswaran or by Tiwari and therefore the dispute continued to remain an individual dispute.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant contended that the dispute was supported by the Bombay Union of Journalists of which Salivateeswaran was a member and that, in any event, it was supported by Venkateswaran and Tiwari, who were the only other employees

holdings.reasoning_summary: Credits affidavits of Venkateswaran and Tiwari denying support or authorization of union action; no evidence of prior espousal.

holdings.text: we are of the view that the evidence tends to establish the plea raised by the first respondent that the record of the alleged resolution was fabricated with a view to support the case of Salivateeswaran.

anchor.surface_text: For reasons to be presently set out, we are of the view that the evidence tends to establish the plea raised by the first respondent that the record of the alleged resolution was fabricated with a view to support the case of Salivateeswaran. The alleged meeting of April 17, 1958, was not convened as an Extraordinary General meeting of the Union.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detailed scrutiny of testimony (Mahatame unreliable), document discrepancies (date alteration, no minutes/notice), absence of records, post-facto conduct show fabrication.

holdings.text: It must be held that the jurisdiction of the labour court to proceed with the matter wholly depends on whether the industrial dispute referred to it for adjudication existed or was apprehended on the date of the reference and not on any subsequent date.

anchor.surface_text: It must be hold that the jurisdiction of the labour court to proceed with the matter wholly depends on whether the industrial dispute referred to it for adjudication existed or was apprehended on the date of the reference and not on any subsequent date.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Approves Madras High Court view in Working Journalists of the Hindu; jurisdiction stems from reference based on existing/apprehended dispute at reference date.

holdings.text: If the dispute was in its inception an individual dispute and continued to be such till the date of the reference by the Government of Bombay, it could not be converted into an industrial dispute by support subsequent to the reference even of workmen interested in the dispute.

anchor.surface_text: If the dispute was in its inception an individual dispute and continued to be such till the date of the reference by the Government of Bombay, it could not be converted into an industrial dispute by support subsequent to the reference even of workmen interested

holdings.reasoning_summary: Symmetrical to withdrawal not affecting jurisdiction; post-reference support (e.g., Indian Federation) irrelevant as jurisdiction fixed at reference.

holdings.text: the Tribunal rejected the first and the second grounds but upheld the third, and holding that the dispute was merely an individual dispute between Salivateeswaran and The Hindu, Bombay, which had not been supported by an appreciable number of employees of The Hindu, Bombay, the Government of Bombay had no jurisdiction to refer the dispute to the Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal rejected the first and the second grounds but upheld the third, and holding that the dispute was merely an individual dispute between Salivateeswaran and The Hindu, Bombay, which had not been supported by an appreciable number of employees of The Hindu, Bombay, the Government of Bombay had no jurisdiction to refer the dispute to the Tribunal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court upholds Tribunal's findings on lack of jurisdiction due to no industrial dispute (third ground); implicitly affirms rejection of first two grounds by not disturbing them.

precedents.citation: Kasturi and Sons Private Ltd. v. Salivateeswaran 1 1959 S. C. R 1

anchor.surface_text: Kasturi and Sons Private Ltd. v. Salivateeswaran 1 1959 S. C. R 1

precedents.case_name: Kasturi and Sons Private Ltd v Salivateeswaran
precedents.cited_proposition: s. 17 of the Act did not empower the Authority to act as a forum for adjudicating disputed claims

precedents.citation: Central Provinces Transport Services Ltd. v. Raghunath Gopal Patwardhan 1 1956 S. C. R. 956

anchor.surface_text: Central Provinces Transport Services Ltd. v. Raghunath Gopal Patwardhan 1 , this Court after setting out the three possible views on the question whether a dispute by an individual workman may be regarded as an industrial dispute within the meaning of s. 2 k  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 observed The preponderance of judicial opinion is clearly in favour of the last of the three views ,stated above  i. e. a dispute between an employer and a single employee cannot per se be an industrial dispute, but it may become one if it is taken up by the Union or a number of workmen and there is companysiderable reason behind it. Notwithstanding that the language of s. 2 k  is wide enough to companyer a dispute between an employer and a single employee, the scheme of the Industrial Disputes Act does appear to companytemplate that the machinery provided therein should be set in motion, to settle only disputes which involve the rights of workmen as a class and that a dispute touching the individual right, of a workman was number intended to be the subject of an adjudication under the Act, when the same had number been taken  1 1956 S. C. R. 956.

precedents.case_name: Central Provinces Transport Services Ltd v Raghunath Gopal Patwardhan
precedents.cited_proposition: a dispute between an employer and a single employee cannot per se be an industrial dispute, but it may become one if it is taken up by the Union or a number of workmen
precedents.cited_holding: the scheme of the Industrial Disputes Act does appear to contemplate that the machinery provided therein should be set in motion, to settle only disputes which involve the rights of workmen as a class

precedents.citation: The Newspapers Ltd. v.The State industrial Tribunal. U. P., i 1957 S. C. R. 754

anchor.surface_text: This view was reiterated in The Newspapers Ltd. v.The State industrial Tribunal. U. P.,  i  Therefore, the applicability of the industrial Disputes Act to an individual dispute as distingushed from a dispute involving a group of workmen a excluded, unless the workmen as a body or a companysiderable section of them make companymon cause with individual workman. 1 1957 S. C. R. 754.

precedents.case_name: Newspapers Ltd v State Industrial Tribunal U P
precedents.cited_proposition: applicability of the Industrial Disputes Act to an individual dispute excluded unless the workmen as a body or a considerable section make common cause with individual workman

precedents.citation: Workmen of Dimakuchi Tea Estate v. The , Management of Dimakuchi Tea Estate 1 1958 S. C. R. 1156

anchor.surface_text: in Workmen of Dimakuchi Tea Estate v. The , Management of Dimakuchi Tea Estate 1 . This Court held by a majority that the two tests of an industrial I dispute as defined by sub-s.  k  of s. 2 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, must,, therefore be- 1  the dispute must be a real dispute capable of being settled by relief given by one party to the other and  2  the person in respect of whom the dispute is raised must be one in whose employment, number-employment, terms of employment, or companyditions of labour  as the case may be , the parties to the dispute have a direct or substantial interest, and this must depend on the facts and circumstances of each case. 1 1958 S. C. R. 1156.

precedents.case_name: Workmen of Dimakuchi Tea Estate v Management of Dimakuchi Tea Estate
precedents.cited_proposition: the persons who seek to support the cause of a workman must themselves be directly and substantially interested in the dispute
precedents.cited_holding: the two tests of an industrial dispute: real dispute and direct or substantial interest of parties in employment etc.

The Hindu 2 . 1 1959 11 L. L. J. 348.

precedents.cited_proposition: jurisdiction of labour court depends on existence of industrial dispute on date of reference, not affected by subsequent withdrawal of support
precedents.cited_holding: jurisdiction stems from the reference based on dispute existing on date of reference
